body:
looking at some test results.

We are changing files that should require re-running all the tests, but we skipped everything but node and python.

We should look into the skipping algorithm again.
Btw, optional: perhaps it is a good idea to set up a bunch of tests for the skipping algorithm and put them in the sanity suite?

```
Finding file differences between gRPC origin/master branch and pull request...

  tools/run_tests/filter_pull_request_tests.py
  tools/run_tests/jobset.py
  tools/run_tests/report_utils.py
  tools/run_tests/run_tests_matrix.py

  sanity tests safe to skip
  c tests safe to skip
  c++ tests safe to skip
  csharp tests safe to skip
  objc tests safe to skip
  php tests safe to skip
  php7 tests safe to skip
  ruby tests safe to skip
  linux tests safe to skip
  windows tests safe to skip
  macos tests safe to skip

These tests will be skipped:
  run_tests_csharp_linux_dbg
  run_tests_ruby_linux_dbg
  run_tests_php7_linux_opt
  run_tests_sanity_linux_opt
  run_tests_c_linux_dbg
  run_tests_php7_linux_dbg
  run_tests_php_linux_dbg
  run_tests_c++_linux_opt
  run_tests_csharp_linux_opt
  run_tests_php_linux_opt
  run_tests_c_linux_opt
  run_tests_sanity_linux_dbg
  run_tests_c++_linux_dbg
  run_tests_ruby_linux_opt

Will run these tests:
  run_tests_node_linux_dbg
  run_tests_node_linux_opt
  run_tests_python_linux_dbg
  run_tests_python_linux_opt
```

The reason for so many skipped tests is because of this: 

```
 # todo(mattkwong): Remove this
 # Faking changed files to test test filtering on Jenkins
 changed_files = ['src/node/something', 'src/python/something']
```

Without this, all tests would run, and I need some tests to skip to see how it shows up in Jenkins.

I agree about making tests for the skipping algorithm. Related to adding them to sanity tests, I have a feeling sanity tests are being skipped too much, but we should go over the whitelist a few more times during the testing period to make sure we're not skipping important tests.

ping @ctiller 

Any feedback on the whitelist would be great. With this, PR testing should be much faster/smoother, but of course we should be concerned that we are not accidently skipping relevant tests.

_WHITELIST_DICT = {
  '^doc/': [],
  '^examples/': [],
  '^include/grpc++/': [_CPP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^summerofcode/': [],
  '^src/cpp/': [_CPP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/csharp/': [_CSHARP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/node/': [_NODE_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/objective-c/': [_OBJC_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/php/': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/python/': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE],
  '^src/ruby/': [_RUBY_TEST_SUITE],
  '^templates/': [_SANITY_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/core/': [_CORE_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/cpp/': [_CPP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/cpp/': [_CPP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/csharp/': [_CSHARP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/node/': [_NODE_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/php/': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/python/': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE],
  '^test/distrib/ruby/': [_RUBY_TEST_SUITE],
  '^vsprojects/': [_WINDOWS_TEST_SUITE],
  'binding.gyp$': [_NODE_TEST_SUITE],
  'composer.json$': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  'config.m4$': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  'CONTRIBUTING.md$': [],
  'Gemfile$': [_RUBY_TEST_SUITE],
  'grpc.def$': [_WINDOWS_TEST_SUITE],
  'grpc.gemspec$': [_RUBY_TEST_SUITE],
  'gRPC.podspec$': [_OBJC_TEST_SUITE],
  'gRPC-Core.podspec$': [_OBJC_TEST_SUITE],
  'gRPC-ProtoRPC.podspec$': [_OBJC_TEST_SUITE],
  'gRPC-RxLibrary.podspec$': [_OBJC_TEST_SUITE],
  'INSTALL.md$': [],
  'LICENSE$': [],
  'MANIFEST.md$': [],
  'package.json$': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  'package.xml$': [_PHP_TEST_SUITE],
  'PATENTS$': [],
  'PYTHON-MANIFEST.in$': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE],
  'README.md$': [],
  'requirements.txt$': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE],
  'setup.cfg$': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE],
  'setup.py$': [_PYTHON_TEST_SUITE]
}

Basically this thing. If any changed files does not match one of these regexes, then all tests will be run. Otherwise, the only tests run are the ones inside the value of the keys matched in the dict. If a value of a key is empty, then that file being changed should not trigger any tests.
